channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Signs of Russia’s Rule Disappear From Kherson, but Its Soldiers Do Not
item.description: The city’s remaining residents are stocking up on food and fuel to survive combat, unsure of what to believe and afraid of what comes next.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged school Thursday in a village in the Kherson region that was formerly occupied by Russian forces.

item.title: Netanyahu to Return to Power in Israel as Lapid Concedes Defeat
item.description: After five elections in less than four years, Israel will have a stable government for the first time since 2019. But Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition could test the constitutional framework and social fabric.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Tuesday. His return to power could strain some of his country’s diplomatic relations, notably with the United States and with Arab states.

item.title: ‘I’m Afraid for My Future’: Proposed Laws Threaten Gay Life in Russia
item.description: The laws, all but assured of enactment, would intensify a crackdown on L.G.B.T.Q. freedom in Russia, which Vladimir V. Putin has cast as a corrosive Western influence.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Valeriya Safronova and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drag show at a gay club in Moscow.

item.title: In Europe, New Refugee Crisis Stirs Uncomfortable Questions
item.description: The war in Ukraine has sent the numbers of refugees seeking shelter in Europe soaring, pushing those from other conflicts to the end of the line.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Basharmal Mohammadi, second from right, lives with other Afghan teenagers a mile from Belgium’s royal palace and under concrete stairs.

item.title: China’s Out-of-Control Rocket Booster Is Headed Back to Earth
item.description: For the fourth time, the country’s space program has used a 23-ton launcher that has scattered debris after previous flights.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A Long March 5B rocket lifting off from China’s satellite launch center in Hainan Province on Monday, in an image released by state media.

item.title: In Bid to Show It Is Open, Hong Kong Bends Covid Rules … for Some
item.description: Three splashy events this week were meant to prove that the former British colony was still “Asia’s World City.” But pandemic exemptions were only doled out to those who could afford them.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times

item.title: 3-Year-Old in China Dies After Covid Restrictions Delayed Care
item.description: When the boy’s father asked for help getting his son to the hospital, he was told to put on a mask. Local officials promised to “learn from this painful lesson.”
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Yang Zhibin/Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Lanzhou, China, in July.

item.title: Imran Khan, Ex-Prime Minister of Pakistan, Is Shot at Rally
item.description: Mr. Khan, who was leading a protest march, was wounded in both legs, in an attack that threated to plunge the country into turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum

item.title: Details in Ethiopia’s Peace Deal Reveal Clear Winners and Losers
item.description: Fighters in the country’s northern Tigray region, who fought a bitter two-year war against the Ethiopian Army, must disarm within 30 days and allow security forces to take control of Tigray’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Ethiopian troops during a ceremony on Thursday to remember those soldiers who died on the first day of the Tigray conflict in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

item.title: Will Qatar Be Ready for the World Cup?
item.description: As sports fans prepare to flood the tiny Gulf nation, cranes and loaders are still running hard — as is criticism of Qatar’s human rights record and exploitation of workers.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Assembling a sign in Doha, Qatar, ahead of the World Cup. As the tournament draws near, Qatari officials have grown increasingly defensive about outside criticism.

item.title: North Korea Fires 6 More Missiles Toward Japan, Including an ICBM
item.description: A day after launching nearly two dozen missiles, the North fired more. One was an intercontinental ballistic missile, but that test apparently failed, an official said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japan’s nationwide J-Alert system broadcasting emergency information in Tokyo, after North Korea fired ballistic missiles on Thursday morning.

item.title: Indian Drugs, Sold Worldwide, Sometimes Deadly
item.description: Deaths believed to be linked to contaminated cough syrups in Gambia have brought attention to loose regulations in India and a lack of testing capacity in poor importing nations.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar, Saikou Jammeh, Mujib Mashal and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The deaths of Gambian children were linked to cough syrups produced by Maiden Pharmaceuticals in India.

item.title: Accusations of Racism Against Lawmaker Roil France’s Parliament
item.description: A far-right member of Parliament shouted that someone should “go back to Africa” while a Black lawmaker was discussing migrants.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: France’s Parliament in session last month.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Has a Boris Johnson Problem
item.description: Already saddled with a budget crisis amid a cost-of-living crisis, the British prime minister has to deal with his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Wednesday. It was Mr. Sunak’s resignation as Boris Johnson’s chancellor of the Exchequer that triggered his boss’s downfall.

item.title: India’s Air Pollution Season Is Off to a Terrible Start.
item.description: Toxic air in northern India this week has prompted school closures, traffic restrictions and political infighting. “We are not breathing air but smoking it,” one activist said.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
item.media:description: As of Thursday afternoon, 18 cities across India had very poor air based on air quality readings many times above what the World Health Organization would consider healthy.

item.title: A Poll Reversal
item.description: Republicans have swiftly gained ground near the end of midterm elections polling.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Timothy Mulcare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting in Manhattan last week.

item.title: As Other Global Crises Collide, Nations Converge to Address Climate Change
item.description: The United States will try to reassert global leadership at global talks in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: 27th Conference of the Parties of the UNFCCC (COP27)
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: COP27, the next United Nations climate summit, begins in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Sunday.

item.title: Five Ways Sanctions Are Hitting Russia
item.description: Russia’s economy and residents have taken a battering, but the government continues to reap big revenues from energy sales. A partial European embargo on oil takes effect in December.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Ana Swanson and Michael Crowley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A closed Zara store in Moscow. Russian imports have dropped sharply, reflecting the decision of multinational companies to sever ties with Russia.

item.title: For Ghana’s Only Openly Transgender Musician, ‘Every Day Is Dangerous’
item.description: Maxine Angel Opoku has found a new audience for her music with songs opposing a proposed law that would make it illegal to identify as gay, transgender or queer.
item.dc:creator: Kwasi Gyamfi Asiedu
item.media:credit: Francis Kokoroko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The musician Maxine Angel Opoku, 37, at her home in Accra, Ghana.

item.title: Ukrainians Turn to Diaries for Solace, and to Share Life in Wartime
item.description: Writers have long used diaries to make sense of life. Now, diaries can be shared in real time, helping shape public perception of events as they unfold — including war.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: A portrait of a volunteer of Kyiv’s Zoo Patrol, by Mila Teshaieva. Teshaieva went from Berlin to Kyiv, her hometown, when the war started, and recorded her impressions in diary entries and photos.

item.title: What a Job Posting That Went Viral Says About New Zealand
item.description: The country is popularly viewed as a place where you can get away from it all, but that doesn’t mean it is without its own entrenched problems.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A forest near the Haast River in New Zealand.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A preview of the U.N. climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A sign posted by the Egyptian Ministry of Environment promotes this year’s United Nations global summit on climate change in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, on Thursday.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 4, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 4, 2022.

item.title: Biden and Netanyahu Gear Up for a Complicated New Era
item.description: The two leaders have forged a relationship over four decades that vacillates between warmth and combat.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, center, the head of Likud party, at an October gathering before elections cemented a path for his return to power.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Corruption Charges in Israel: What to Know
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu is on track to once again lead Israel as prime minister — while facing a corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu is poised to begin a sixth term as prime minister.

item.title: Kherson Braces for Battle as Russian Administration Evacuates
item.description: Evidence points to both sides preparing for a pitched battle for the southern city, and Ukrainians say hints of a Russian military withdrawal are mere deception.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A damaged building in the village of Arkhanhelske, in the Kherson region, on Thursday. The building was formerly occupied by Russian forces.

item.title: Karpov, Former Chess Champion, Is Injured After Fall in Moscow
item.description: Mr. Karpov has been a loyal defender of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, and the invasion of Ukraine. But he has also expressed sympathy for the war’s civilian victims on both sides.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: The Russian chess grandmaster Anatoly Karpov at an international chess festival in Spain in 2019.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A COP 27 Preview
item.description: Plus Benjamin Netanyahu retakes power in Israel and Imran Khan is wounded in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Beijing. China has long viewed coal, which it has in abundance, as the best way to avoid becoming overly dependent on foreign energy suppliers.

item.title: Troubled Loner? Political Terrorist? Both? It’s Often Hard to Say
item.description: The attack on Nancy Pelosi’s husband has raised questions about the role of demonizing political speech in violent acts, not for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday, as she left her home where her husband, Paul, suffered an attack by David DePape.

item.title: Battle Over Deep-Sea Mining Takes on New Urgency as Trial Run Winds Down
item.description: A Canadian company is testing mining equipment in the Pacific Ocean in its quest for metals needed for electric vehicles. Environmentalists oppose the mining, which could begin in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Charles M. Vella/SOPA Images, via LightRocket — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Rotterdam projected statements onto the Hidden Gem, a ship used by the Metals Company.

item.title: The U.N.’s nuclear watchdog finds no evidence for Russia’s claim that Ukraine is readying a ‘dirty bomb.’
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said its inspections had found no evidence of illegal nuclear activity at three sites that figured in Russia’s claims.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rafael M. Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog, after visiting the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex in September.

item.title: US Officials Met With Brittney Griner in Russia, White House Says
item.description: The meeting was the first since the basketball star’s appeal on a drug conviction in Russia was rejected.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr., Chris Cameron and Edward Wong
item.media:description: WNBA basketball player Brittney Griner arrives to a hearing at the Khimki Court, outside Moscow in August.

item.title: A Warming Siberia, Wracked by Wildfires, Nears a Crucial Threshold
item.description: Nearly 23 million acres burned from 1982 to 2020. But almost half of that occurred in 2019 and 2020, and the region may be near a threshold beyond which extreme fires become more common.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A downed power line near Magaras in northeastern Siberia in July 2021. Wildfire smoke cloaked the area.

item.title: Hannah Pick-Goslar, a Presence in Anne Frank’s Diary, Dies at 93
item.description: The two young women knew each other from kindergarten until their final encounter, on opposite sides of a barbed-wire fence in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Anne Frank Fonds - Basel via Getty Images

item.title: UK Takes Sides Over Bounty Chocolate
item.description: Bounty, a chocolate-coconut concoction similar to Mounds, will be left out of some Celebrations holiday assortments this year, stirring a national debate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor

item.title: Suspect in Pelosi Attack Was in the US Illegally, Officials Say
item.description: David DePape, a Canadian, legally entered the United States in 2008. He faces several state and federal charges after the authorities say he broke into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home and assaulted her husband.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:description: Police officers outside Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home in San Francisco last week.

item.title: Can a Nation Replace Its Oil Wealth With Trees?
item.description: Gabon knows its oil won’t last forever, so officials are turning to the Central African nation’s rainforest for revenue — while also promising to preserve it.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Arlette Bashizi

item.title: Brutal Fight for Kherson Still Looms Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainian officials have warned that Moscow could be trying to create the illusion of a pullback to draw Ukrainian forces into a trap.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers returning to a village to spend the night last week before heading to the front line in the Kherson region. Ukrainian officials have said they expect a brutal battle for the city of Kherson.

item.title: As Dollar Strengthens, U.S. Students in Europe Feel the Benefits
item.description: The pound and the euro are trading at decades-long lows against the dollar. For American students abroad, that has made weekend trips, dinners and theater tickets (somewhat) less of a splurge.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avery Scott, a junior at the University of Georgia, is currently studying at the University of Oxford in England, where her money has gone further because of the falling value of the British pound.

item.title: The Job Market’s Cues
item.description: Two measurements tell two stories about the strength of U.S. employment.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Office workers in Manhattan earlier this year.

item.title: Nations Must Increase Funding to Cope With Climate Shocks, U.N. Warns
item.description: Failing to help developing nations brace for disruption will lead to increased conflict and widespread suffering, the United Nations wrote in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: An collapsing walkway in Bargny, a fishing town about 10 miles south of Dakar, the Senegalese capital.

item.title: Shelling Cuts Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant’s Connection to Outside Power
item.description: It is at least the fourth time the facility has lost connection to outside power since Russian forces began occupying it early in the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant seen from Nikopol, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Signing the agreement on Wednesday in Pretoria, South Africa, to stop the fighting in the Tigray region of Ethiopia were Redwan Hussien, left, the Ethiopian government’s national security adviser, and Getachew Reda, a senior leader in the Tigray People’s Liberation Front

item.title: G7 foreign ministers meet in Germany to make plans to aid Ukraine against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A displaced family from the Russian occupied city of Enerhodar at a humanitarian center in Zaporizhzia, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia’s Nuclear Weapons Rhetoric: How Concerned Should We Be?
item.description: U.S. officials say they do not believe that Russia has decided to detonate a tactical device, but concerns are rising.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has raised the specter of nuclear weapons in his war with Ukraine, but experts say the risk remains very low.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Removal of Iran From U.N. Women’s Rights Agency
item.description: At an informal meeting of the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday, the American ambassador called on the global community to give its “moral support” to protesters in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Shirin Ebadi, an Iranian human rights lawyer and Nobel Peace Prize winner, addressing via a live video link an informal meeting of the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday, regarding the ongoing women-led protests in Iran.

item.title: Angry Bolsonaro Supporters Protest in the Streets
item.description: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in cities across Brazil, many of them demanding that the military stop the transfer of power to President-elect Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro gathering outside the Brazilian Army’s national headquarters on Wednesday in Brasília, the capital.

item.title: Russia Rejoins Grain Deal, but Warns It Could Pull Out Again
item.description: The agreement allows Ukraine, a major food producer, to export grain by sea, easing the threat of famine in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Malta-flagged bulk carrier Zante transiting the Bosporus on Wednesday en route to Belgium while carrying over 52,000 tons of rapeseed from Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Truce in Tigray
item.description: Plus North Korea fired a record number of missiles, and Russia rejoined the grail deal.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: From left: Representatives from Ethiopia, the mediation team and the Tigray rebels during a news conference in Pretoria, South Africa, on Wednesday.

item.title: Dobby’s Grave Can Stay on a Beach in Wales, but Please Stop Giving Him Socks
item.description: After a grave site for the “Harry Potter” elf became a tourist attraction, tributes to the character prompted environmental concerns.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (Movie)
item.media:description: “Harry Potter” fans erected a memorial to Dobby the elf on the beach in Wales where the character’s death was filmed.

item.title: Israel’s Election: 5 Takeaways
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu seems poised to take power again. But regardless of his fate, the election already highlights several trends that could have a lasting effect on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Tuesday. Mr. Netanyahu seemed poised to take power again after the Israeli election.

item.title: Iranian Authorities Crack Down on Protests at Tehran Apartment Complex
item.description: Iran’s security forces shot at windows and threw stun grenades in a raid at the Shahrak Ekbatan complex, where a member of the feared Basij militia was killed last week, residents said.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iranians protest the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini in Tehran on Thursday. Ms. Amini died after she was detained by the morality police.

item.title: Ethiopia and Tigray Rebels Agree to End Civil War, Mediators Say
item.description: After two years of fighting that left hundreds of thousands dead and millions displaced and facing starvation, the surprise deal came out of peace talks convened by the African Union in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Signing the agreement on Wednesday in Pretoria, South Africa, to stop the fighting in the Tigray region of Ethiopia were Redwan Hussien, the Ethiopian government’s national security adviser, and Getachew Reda, a senior leader in the Tigray People’s Liberation Front.

item.title: North Korea Sending Ammunition to Russia for War, White House Says
item.description: The national security spokesman, John Kirby, said that it was unclear if the munitions had reached Russia, but that in any case, they would not “change the course of the war.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The White House’s national security spokesman, John Kirby, during a news briefing in September.

item.title: Kyiv Prepares 425 Shelters in Case of a Russian Nuclear Attack
item.description: Worries that the Kremlin might turn to its nuclear arsenal have deepened since President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the specter of using such weapons to hold on to territorial gains.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The basement of a cafe that doubles as a bomb shelter last month in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: The New Abortion Landscape
item.description: Women in states with abortion bans are turning to telemedicine.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:description: Misoprostol is used to terminate early pregnancies.

item.title: Denmark’s Center-Left Coalition Wins Election Majority
item.description: An unpredictable race ultimately gave the governing Social Democratic Party its best showing in two decades, though analysts said it looked set to form a more centrist government.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said she wanted a “broad government,” reaching across the political spectrum.

item.title: Hurricane or Typhoon? How Tropical Cyclones Get Their Names.
item.description: There are variations around the world, particularly in the Western Pacific, in how countries name and measure tropical cyclones. We can explain.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A man walking along the beach after Typhoon Noru passed Da Nang, Vietnam, in September.

item.title: As Climate Change Worsens, US Weighs Which Communities to Save
item.description: Native American tribes are competing for the first federal grants designed to help move communities away from high water and other dangers posed by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Tailyr Irvine
item.media:credit: Tailyr Irvine for The New York Times

item.title: After Covid Lockdown, Fear and Unrest Sweep iPhone Factory in China
item.description: Hundreds of workers are said to have fled, afraid of being forced into quarantine with inadequate food and supplies.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: People leaving a Foxconn compound in Zhengzhou, China, on Saturday.

item.title: Netanyahu Extends Lead in Israel Election, Projections Say
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s near-certain victory in this week’s election in Israel won’t be confirmed until Thursday, but his far right allies are already savoring their rise to power.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, right, in Jerusalem on Tuesday. With about two-thirds of the vote counted, Israel’s three main broadcasters were projecting that Mr. Netanyahu’s party, Likud, would finish first.
